"step_by_step_thinking": "The question asks if there is a differential in the dental health of new recruits to the British Armed Forces. Since the provided documents are about Norwegian recruits (1988) and US Air Force members (1977), we can't directly answer this question. However, we can analyze these studies to see if they provide any insights on dental health differences among military recruits.

The 1988 study found that 23.7% of all Norwegian recruits had no decayed teeth, with an average DMFT score of 12.1 and the number of decayed surfaces was 4.1. The study also showed little change in regular dental attendance patterns from 1968 to 1988.

The 1977 US Air Force survey found a significant level of unmet dental needs among active-duty members, with recruits requiring an average of ten hours and 23 minutes of dental treatment.

These studies don't provide direct evidence on differences in dental health between new recruits to the British Armed Forces. However, they do suggest that there may be some variations in dental health and treatment needs within military recruit populations based on different countries or time periods.",
